chunk_summary: Outpatient management of uncomplicated enteric fever includes cefixime or azithromycin as first-line antibiotics, with supportive care and close monitoring for complications or resistance.
learning_objectives: Understand the first-line antibiotic regimens for uncomplicated enteric fever in outpatient settings.
Recognize the importance of monitoring clinical response and danger signs in children with enteric fever.
Learn supportive care measures, including hydration, fever management, and nutritional support.
Identify when to escalate care for suspected complications or treatment failure.
key_facts: Cefixime 20 mg/kg/day (divided twice daily) for 10–14 days is a practical first-line oral regimen.
Azithromycin 20 mg/kg once daily (max 1 g/day) for 7 days is an effective alternative.
Co-trimoxazole (trimethoprim 8 mg/kg/day, divided twice daily for 14 days) is a stewardship-friendly option if susceptibility allows.
Fever may persist for 4–7 days despite effective therapy; monitor overall condition and fever trends.
Reassessment within 48 hours is recommended, with urgent return advised for worsening symptoms.
Empiric fluoroquinolones are generally avoided in children due to resistance and safety concerns.
reference_quote: Antibiotics should be started after blood culture is collected when feasible, but treatment should not be delayed in a strongly suspected case. (National Treatment Guidelines for Antimicrobial Use in Infectious Diseases, India)
